title: Increasing the Fish Population
question_text:
A state Wildlife and Fisheries agent is trying to stimulate the growth of the population of a certain type of fish. She will conduct an experiment that involves randomly assigning 3 different treatments to 36 fish to determine which treatment will cause the largest amount of weight gain in the fish. The agent wants to make sure that the 3 treatment groups each have exactly 12 fish.
Which of the following methods should be used to assign the treatments?

choices.text:
Catch 36 fish
. For each fish roll a six-sided number cube. If the cube shows a 1
or 2
, the fish will receive treatment 'A'. If the cube shows a 3
or 4
, the fish will receive treatment 'B'. If the cube shows a 5
or 6
, the fish will receive treatment 'C'.

As each fish is caught, draw a number from a random digit table. If the number is 1
, 2
, or 3
, the fish will receive treatment 'A'. If the number is 4
, 5
, or 6
, the fish will receive treatment 'B'. If the number is 7
, 8
, or 9
, the fish will receive treatment 'C'. If the number is 0
, a new number will be drawn. If a treatment group already has 12 fish
then another number will be chosen to assign the fish to one of the other groups.

The first
12
 fish
caught will be assigned to treatment 'A', the second
12
 fish
to treatment 'B' and the last
12
 fish
to treatment 'C'.

Catch
36
 fish
and assign each fish a unique number between
1
and
36
. Write the numbers from
1
to
36
on separate slips of paper. Place the slips in a fish bowl and mix them up. Draw
12
 slips
of paper. The fish corresponding to those numbers will receive treatment 'A'. Draw
12
 more slips
of paper. The fish corresponding to those numbers will receive Treatment 'B'. The remaining fish will receive treatment 'C'.

All of these methods will randomly assign the treatments to
3
 groups
of
12
 fish
.

solution:
Choice 'D' seems inconvenient, but it is the only choice that describes a truly random assignment of treatment for all
36
 fish
.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' does not guarantee
12
 fish
in each group. By rolling dice, there is random assignment, but there could be
20
 fish
in the first group,
12
 fish
in the second group, and
4
 fish
in the third group.

Choice 'B' is not completely random because the last few fish that are caught are placed in the group that is not full yet. This introduces a confounding variable because the last few fish that are caught are probably faster or stronger fish who will all show good growth for the treatment they receive.

Choice 'C' includes no randomness and leaves the experiment vulnerable to a confounding variable. It could be that the first
12
 fish
caught are the slower, weaker fish and would show the least amount of growth at the end of the experiment regardless of the treatment they received.
